sect1.title: Making Backups and Restores
sect1.para: &ds389; supports making offline and online backups. The dsctl command makes offline database backups, and the dsconf command makes online database backups. Back up the LDAP server configuration directory, to enable complete restoration in case of a major failure.

sect2.title: Backing Up the Server Configuration
sect2.para: Your LDAP server configuration is in /etc/dirsrv/slapd-instance-name. This contains certificates, keys, and the dse.ldif file. Make a compressed backup of this directory with the tar command:
sect2.screen: &prompt.sudo;tar caf config_slapd-ldap1_$(date +%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M-%S).tar.gz /etc/dirsrv/slapd-ldap1/ tar: Removing leading `/' from member names
sect2.para: To restore this configuration, move the existing configuration (if it exists), unpack the backup archive, and copy it to /etc/dirsrv/slapd-instance-name:

sect2.title: Offline Database Backup and Restore
sect2.para: The dsctl command makes offline backups. Stop the server, then make the backup using your instance name:
sect2.screen: &prompt.sudo;dsctl ldap1 stop Instance "ldap1" has been stopped &prompt.sudo;dsctl ldap1 db2bak db2bak successful
sect2.para: This example creates a backup archive at /var/lib/dirsrv/slapd-ldap1/bak/ldap1-2021_07_26_13_03_17.
Restore from this backup, naming the directory containing the backup archive:
sect2.screen: &prompt.sudo;dsctl ldap1 start Instance "ldap1" has been started
sect2.para: You may also create LDIF backups:
sect2.screen: &prompt.sudo;dsctl ldap1 db2ldif --replication userRoot ldiffile: /var/lib/dirsrv/slapd-ldap1/ldif/ldap1-userRoot-2021_07_28_08_47_30.ldif db2ldif successful
sect2.para: Restore this backup with the name of the archive, then start the server:

sect2.title: Online Database Backup and Restore
sect2.para: Use the dsconf to make an online backup of your LDAP database:
sect2.screen: &prompt.sudo;dsconf ldap1 backup create The backup create task has finished successfully
